snippet: The rule change, which takes effect on Wednesday, would let out-of-state lawyers working as counsel for corporations offer their services to the poor without restrictions.
abstract: New York State Chief Judge Jonathan Lippman announces that out-of-state lawyers who work as counsel for large corporations in New York State will be allowed to do pro bono work; rule change is intended to ease an acute shortage of legal representation for state's impoverished residents in civil courts; Lippman estimates that change would allow nonprofit legals services to tap a reservoir of about 5,000 volunteer attorneys.
lead_paragraph: The rule change, which takes effect on Wednesday, would let out-of-state lawyers working as counsel for corporations offer their services to the poor without restrictions.

headline.main: Rule Change Could Ease ‘Justice Gap’ for the Poor
headline.print_headline: Rule Change Could Ease ‘Justice Gap’ For the Poor
